title: Do teachers dislike students with terrible grades? - Quora

response.answer_text: Probably. Before you get me wrong, read this, please. As the question says terrible grades, I assume they do. Why? Because when students that are not very good at something (or at school in general) try hard, their grades might be bad, but not terrible. When somebody gets terrible grades (from what I see in my school at least) is because they are not putting much effort (any effort) in getting better ones. I have a friend who finds school very difficult and challenging, but she tries hard, studies a lot and always brings the homework done. She’s nlt been getting terrible grades, but they’re not good either, I would call them “below average”. The teachers love her. There’s another one (not really a friend) who does not care about school at all. He is always late (me too but let’s ignore that), doesn’t study nor does any homework (hardly), he sometimes turns blank exams in… He gets terrible grades. The teachers can’t stand him. I’m not a studying role model either, but I work a lot less than I could (even though it’s way more than him) and I get really good grades. Most of my teachers love me, other don’t. From what I observed, teachers dislike students who put no effort in what they’re doing or don’t care about them. Terrible grades usually mean no effort, and teachers are not amused by that. No effort can still achieve decent grades, but that’s likely to go unnoticed. Good grades (or really good grades) can still be achieved with very little effort sometimes, and that’s gonna drive some teachers crazy. Mad. Angry. Some teachers loves these students, lots of them do, but others can’t stand them either. It’s more about the attitude than about the grades.

No. If they are trying their best and are negatively affected by circumstances beyond their control, we have great sympathy and admiration for them. We also know that success in life is not determined by the grades you get at school, but by grit, determination and hard work, and we try to keep reminding them of this. It is terribly sad when an otherwise fabulous human being loses self confidence because their grades are poor. Newsflash! Your grades don’t determine your worth as a human being. Plus, even with poor grades, you can still achieve your dreams. You just might have to take a non-traditional route to get there. However, if the student has the ability to get good grades but just can’t be bothered, and is trying to soft-soap me with lies and excuses, then I don’t have a lot of sympathy. Be honest with yourself. Are you really a hard worker, or would you just like me to think you are? I’ve seen it all, kiddo, and any lie you can tell me, I’ve heard a thousand times before.

Not at all. I don’t dislike a student because of his or her grades. The reason I would dislike a student have to do with the same reasons people generally dislike others. Things that make me dislike a student include: Being mean to me.Being mean to other students.Bullying.Willful defiance.Making baseless accusations toward me.Frequently disrupting my class.Of course I want all my students to get good grades. I will do anything I can to help them achieve good grades. That even includes students who exhibit challenging behaviors like those listed above. But I don’t dislike students who are unable to achieve academically in my class or any class solely because of their failure to achieve. That being said, most students who have extreme difficulties passing many or most of their classes usually do exhibit some of the above behaviors. So there is a correlation between poor conduct and poor grades.

Nope. Some kids try damn hard in my class, but can’t manage the academic requirements. Others may be working full-time hours to help support their family, or taking care of their brothers and sisters while their Mom picks up another job to help make ends meet. As long as you try your hardest, I will try my hardest. Just because you can’t master my subject doesn’t mean you don’t have value as a person.

Teachers do not dislike students with bad grades. Teacher often understand the reasons that the student has bad grades: poor parent support, bad attendance, difficulty with the subject, immaturity etc. Teacher often have a hard time with students who feel a strong sense of entitlement. Some kids feel that they are more deserving or priviledged that others. Often their own parents have convinced the child that they are superior to others. The parents will not accept their little darling broke a rule or hurt another students. Entitlement is obnoxious.

Generally no. We might dislike a student who bullies or who pointlessly goofs off or who is arrogant about not doing the work, but even in those cases there are often reasons that can be addressed to lead the student onto a better path. Bad grades are a symptom of a problem, not evidence that the student is a bad person.

No, if that is their best and we know it, no problems. If they have a terrible attitude turn up late without books or pens. Never do homework or assignments and then complain when they fail, THESE we hate!
Definitely not, in fact most of my favourite students were not the most intelligent students. Teachers like students who are good people… good people are not always those that get good marks.
No..it's those that make the Teacher's Job worth it. .The teacher is meant to make every student excell and those with poor grades are a Teacher's priority
